question: In rheumatoid arthritis, do citrullinated proteins externalized in neutrophil extracellular traps disrupt the inflammatory cycle by reducing proinflammatory cytokine and chemokine production in target cells? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: In turn, NETs significantly augmented inflammatory responses in RA and OA synovial fibroblasts, including induction of IL-6, IL-8, chemokines, and adhesion molecules.
content.source_2: In neutrophils isolated from patients with rheumatoid arthritis, export of citrullinated antigens during NETosis correlated with a dampening of fibroblast cytokine secretion, and anti-citrullinated vimentin antibodies were observed to inhibit, rather than trigger, NET formation.
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Citrullinated H4 from activated neutrophils and NETs is a target of antibodies in RA, and synthetic citrullinated H4-derived peptides are a new substrate for ACPA detection.
content.source_4: Experimental modeling indicated that histone deimination accompanying NET release represses pro-inflammatory transcriptional programs in synovial cells, thereby interrupting the feed-forward inflammatory cycle.
